hints.content: We can use the formula $V = lwh$ to compare the volume in the two boxes.

First let's compare the volume of both boxes to see if they have the **same** height. To make it simple, let's use a height of $1$ centimeter.

First the box with the smaller base.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b2e887009831d5aab6505e19d27f30be83100456)

$\begin{align}V & = lwh \\\\
V & = 5\cdot 5\cdot 1 \\\\
V & =25\end{align} $

Now the box with the larger base

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2277abc61367381247026dbb48fdc6c868b38c2a)

$\begin{align}V & = lwh \\\\
V & = 10\cdot 10\cdot 1 \\\\
V & =100\end{align} $

We can set up an equation to find out how many times as tall the smaller box needs to be to have the same volume as the box with the larger base.

$\begin{align} 25\cdot h & = 100\\\\
h & = 4 \end{align}$
To have a volume of $100\text{ cm}^3$, the height of the box with the smaller base needs to be $4\text{ cm}$. The height of the box with the larger base is $1\text{ cm}$.
The box with the smaller base is $4$ times as tall.

question.content:
Two boxes have the same volume. One box has a base that is $5\text{ cm}$ by $5\text{ cm}$. The other box has a base that is $10\text{ cm}$ by $10\text{ cm}$. 

**How many times as tall is the box with the smaller base?**
